articles.headline: Business Quietly Returns to Saudi Arabia After Khashoggi’s Murder
articles.snippet: Six months after agents from Saudi Arabia dismembered the writer Jamal Khashoggi, investors are no longer shying away from doing business with the kingdom.
articles.abstract: Six months after agents from Saudi Arabia dismembered the writer Jamal Khashoggi, investors are no longer shying away from doing business with the kingdom.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Six months after agents from Saudi Arabia murdered and dismembered the writer Jamal Khashoggi, companies are no longer shying away from the Arab kingdom.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced, Stanley Reed and Daisuke Wakabayashi

articles.headline: As Rich Lavish Cash on Notre-Dame, Many Ask: What About the Needy?
articles.snippet: The spectacle of billionaires trying to one-up each other quickly intensified resentments over inequality that have animated the Yellow Vest movement.
articles.abstract: The spectacle of billionaires trying to one-up each other quickly intensified resentments over inequality that have animated the Yellow Vest movement.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The pledges came in quick succession.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: White House and Justice Dept. Officials Discussed Mueller Report Before Release
articles.snippet: Some of President Trump’s advisers are concerned about whether he will retaliate against them if the report reveals them as sources of damaging details.
articles.abstract: Some of President Trump’s advisers are concerned about whether he will retaliate against them if the report reveals them as sources of damaging details.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Not all of Robert S. Mueller III’s findings will be news to President Trump when they are released Thursday.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Maggie Haberman, Nicholas Fandos and Katie Benner

articles.headline: North Korea Tests New Weapon
articles.snippet: North Korea had declared a moratorium on missile tests after the launch of an intercontinental ballistic missile in November 2017.
articles.abstract: North Korea had declared a moratorium on missile tests after the launch of an intercontinental ballistic missile in November 2017.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — North Korea said on Thursday that it test-fired a new type of “tactical guided weapon,” in what appeared to be a warning from Kim Jong-un to President Trump that unless once-promising negotiations with Washington resume, the two countries could again be on a collision course.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Choe Sang-Hun

articles.headline: 2020 Democrats Seek Voters in an Unusual Spot: Fox News
articles.snippet: A network known for conservative commentary and staunch loyalty to the president is drawing Democratic candidates eager for a big platform with access to Trump voters.
articles.abstract: A network known for conservative commentary and staunch loyalty to the president is drawing Democratic candidates eager for a big platform with access to Trump voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is an unlikely new hot spot for Democratic candidates: Fox News.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: Pinterest Prices I.P.O. at $19 a Share, for a $12.7 Billion Valuation
articles.snippet: The shares will begin trading Thursday on the New York Stock Exchange under the ticker symbol PINS.
articles.abstract: The shares will begin trading Thursday on the New York Stock Exchange under the ticker symbol PINS.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Pinterest on Wednesday priced its shares at $19 each for its initial public offering, in a sign of healthy demand by investors after the appetite for fast-growing but money-losing tech companies appeared to be on the wane.

articles.headline: Excerpts and Analysis From the Mueller Report
articles.snippet: The Justice Department released a redacted version of the special counsel’s report on Thursday. Times reporters uncovered the biggest findings and shared excerpts and analysis.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department released a redacted version of the special counsel’s report on Thursday. Times reporters uncovered the biggest findings and shared excerpts and analysis.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a sweeping, 22-month investigation, Robert S. Mueller III found there was insufficient evidence to establish that President Trump or his associates engaged in a criminal conspiracy with Russia to disrupt the 2016 election, despite numerous contacts between his campaign and Russians. Mr. Mueller’s report also detailed the president’s efforts to thwart the investigation, and the investigators debated whether the episodes amounted to criminal obstruction of justice.

articles.headline: Barr’s Defense of Trump Rewards the President With the Attorney General He Wanted
articles.snippet: At a news conference before he released the special counsel’s report, William P. Barr presented the findings in the best possible light for the president.
articles.abstract: At a news conference before he released the special counsel’s report, William P. Barr presented the findings in the best possible light for the president.
articles.lead_paragraph: For 21 minutes on Thursday morning, with the nation watching, President Trump had the loyal attorney general he had always longed for.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Katie Benner
